Finishes a little abruptly which is the only area I would expect a bit more. Overal. a very impressive offering her. and especially for the price ($19.99). This wine could easily hang next to a Frank Family or Freemark Abbey Caberne. that costs twice as much (and ye. I know Costco sells both of thos. and a side by side with this bottle would be very interesting). CostcoWineBlog.com Rating: 90 Point. Costco item number: 44441. ABV: 14.6. Purchased at Costco in: Atlant. GA (Kennesaw)

Review_name: 2013 Kirkland Signature Series Oakville Cabernet Sauvignon
Review_content: So I’ve picked up quite a few new Kirkland Signature offerings that have hit the stores by m. and there’s a lot of the. more than I’ll be able to review in the next month or s. but you can bet I’m going to give it a shot. And I’m going to start with a few bottles that I’m really curious about – the Cabs from great areas of Napa. They follow an awesome year in 2012 with an almost equally awesome year in 2013. So today we’ll take a look at the 2013 Oakville Caberne. one of my favorite areas of Napa. Price was $18.99. This is a very nice Napa Cab that you would pay twice this price tag for in almost any other form. I love this one. What a steal for $19.Dark pou. and fruit forward nos. slight spice with pepper aromas. In the mout. this wine is a jo. loads of dark fruit and blackcherr. undertones of dark chocolate and moch.something on the finish I just can’t get my taste buds on but I’ve been there befor. almost likethe lumber aisle at Home Depot (I think the pros call it pencil shavings). This is a very composed win. centered and easy to understand. I just gave it an hour in glass and came back and it’s even better. I’m a huge fan. Great buy here. CostcoWineBlog.com Rating: 90 Point. Costco item number: 86666. Purchased at Costco in: Atlant. GA (Kennesaw)

I’ve written before about how wine is often situationa. meaning that wines can taste different just in the environment in which they’re consumed. And this wine falls into a bucket of being consumed in a “very optimal environment.” That is: group of friend. nice spring da. vegetables and pork tenderloins cooking on a Big Green Egg…absolutely perfect. So the wine wa. absolutely perfect as well. This was $16.99 at my Costc. and for some reason I really felt pulled toward this wine. I like the 60% Malbe. 40% Bonarda comb. and it was a bit of change from the regular straight Cabs and standard varietal red blends I’ve been enjoying lately. And what a perfect day to do it. First of. if you’re cooking Pork Tenderloins on a Big Green Egg (and I’m talking about that awesome Costco two pack that is actually a four pack that you can get for under $20. try direct heat vs indirect heat with the plate setter. I know there’s an ongoing debate about this on the Egg forum. but set your Egg to 35. and cook direct until 140 degrees and you are golden. The Costco Pork Tenderloin packs just do not have enough fat on them to stay moist under indirect cooking for too long. Plus you get a better crust going direct. Alrigh. if you’re an Egg Head like m. that just made sens. otherwis. let’s talk about the wine. This one is spicy and earthy on the nose. In the mout. and after some ai. it’s quite nic. rather complex at this price poin. with dark frui. a fair amount ofpeppe.has some acidic bite and just keeps coming. This can stand up to any red mea. or other challenging cuisine. It’s bol. but I really love it since it’s delivered in such a great package. This is a bi. rich red. Lots of spice/pepper backing that big fruit. Get settled in and readybut I’d say go for it. CostcoWineBlog.com Rating: 89 Point. Costco item number: 22503. Purchased at Costco in: Atlant. GA (Cumberland)

I dropped this bottle into my cart on a whim thinking that I had tried it befor. but I couldn’t find any tasting note. so I guess this is my first review of this wine. Either wa. this bottle is a steal for $9.99. It’s super ripe and fruit. tasting at times (particularly the finish before it got air) like those large canned Hawaiian Punch containers you enjoyed as a kid that had to open at both ends with a bottle opener and pour in a glass. As it sat in the glass for a while it developed into a rather nice Bordeaux drinking perfectly right now. This wine is 100% Merlot in a really enjoyable expression of the grap. and agai. quite a bargain at this price. It soft and light having aged a whil. delicate in the mout. flavors of ja. cherry and fruit punc. candy on the finish; finish is dry and chalky. I think you could pour this blind to someone and tell them it was a much more expensive Bordeaux and they might not bat an eye. Good value her. especially for right bank Bordeaux fans. CostcoWineBlog.com Rating: 88 Point. Costco item number: 100922. Purchased at Costco in: Atlant. GA

I have definitely purchased these Kirkland Champagnes in the pas. but just realized after searching through the archive. that I must not have reviewed them for some reason. Perhaps I purchased for a dinner party and didn’t make notes. Regardles. this is a real deal Champagn. meaning it is from the Champagne region of France. Go to another wine shop and see how many bottles of true Champagne they have for $19.99. The answer i. not man. if any. So this is a good bargain if the French bubbly is what you’re after. I’m beginning to go for bubbly more and more. These bottles can really be paired with anything. Tonight with the champagn. we made pork and slaw taco. and it was fine (side not. the pork tenderloin two packs at Costco that go for $13-18 are an insane buy. There’s actually two decent sized tenderloins in each pac. so you’re getting a total of fou. each one of which can be a meal for a whole family). So ye. bubbly wines can go with anything. The only reason I paired with the pork tacos is to do this revie. but it all worked out. O. on to the Champagne. This is a classic dry bubbly. It’s made from a blend of 50% Pinot Noi. 35% Pinot Meunier and15% Chardonna. the standard Champagne grapes. Definitely fruit. citrus mostly with a slight crea. a bit of a yeast/almond edge towards the finish. Dry and crisp finish. Very good wine for the price and a definite addition to the Top Picks list. This is a Kirkland staple that you should be able to find in your local warehouse. CostcoWineBlog.com Rating: 89 Point. Costco item number: 94210. Purchased at Costco in: Atlant. GA (Cumberland)

This bottle is always a go-to for m. whether I’m at a restaurant looking for a reasonably priced wine I know I can depend o. or if I’m just looking for a versatil. food friendly bottle that I can always put on the table no matter who’s sitting around it. For $16.99 at Costc. thisbottle is a solid buy for all red wine fans. It drinks like it cost at least 2X that price. Thisbottle is considered a Super Tusca.meaning it’s a blend of several red grapesthat falls outside of the traditional Italian winemakingclassifications (if you want to dive further into Italian winemaking for more info on thi. check out our boo. Decoding Italian Wine). In this cas. the blend is 55% Sangioves. 25% Cabernet Sauvigno. 15% Merlot and 5% Syrah. The wine starts earthy and spicy on the nose with dried frui. and then opens up with rich red fruit and cherry flavors; feels tight and tannic in the mouth; finishes super dry and sticky. Lots to like here at this pric. so I’ll be adding itto our Top Picks list. It’s been a couple years since I reviewed one of these wine. but I’m going to stay with the 91 points I awarded the ’08 vintage. These are great wines for the money. CostcoWineBlog.com Rating: 91 Point. Costco item number: 79929. Purchased at Costco in: Atlant. GA (Cumberland)

After I tasted and reviewed the 2001 vintage of this winejust a few months ag. I went back to Costco to buy more. At $40 I thought this was the steal of all steals and pretty much said as much in my revie. giving it a nice 93 point rating (Parker has gone 96 pts on these wines). But when I arrived at my Costco all of the 2001 bottles were gone and they only had the 2004. Tip: the 2001s have a red band on the top around the neck while the 2004s have a gold band. This is when I go into super Costco wine fan model. I started digging under the wooden bins. This should be standard practice at most Costcos because you never know what you will find under there (often times free wooden wine boxes too). I was half way around the entire wooden display when I spotted some bottles in the back. They had a red band. Much to the chagrinof the people around me (Christmas time) with their huge shopping carts trying to get through the wine aisle to get a sausage sampl. I pulled more boxes out until I got in the very back and found those two bottles with the red label. Ala. it was what I was looking for – the last two bottles of the 2001 vintage. So I obviously purchased those for the cella. and figured I should try the 2004 for my readers who will likely be able to find that one a little easier (if your experience at your local Costco is anything like mine). But still remembe. it pays to dig around at Costco. So tonight I’m enjoying the 200. and it’s a splendid wine as wel. very much in the same light as the 2001. But the depth of a few years of extra age can be noticed. These bottles are a lot of fun to sip in 30 minute intervals out of a decanter to taste how the wine progresses over time. This bottle started out juic. just waiting for the cork to be busted out. It was bright lively and slightly chilled (it was stored in the cellar with the others). As it came to room temp in the decanter over the course of two hour. I began to enjoy it as much as the ’01. Herbs and vegetal on the nose; flavors ofdark frui. black te. a hint drier on the finish than I remember the ’01. All around a beaut. a fine food wine and worth every bit of the $40 price tag at Costco. I’m going to stay with the same 93 points as I gave the ’01. This is one of the best values in the warehouse. CostcoWineBlog.com Rating: 93 Point. Costco item number: 1132. Purchased at Costco in: Atlant. GA (Kennesaw)

Beaulieu is one of the grande dames of California winemaking – they’ve been producing world-class wines since before most of us were born. And these folks know how to make cabernet wines – their George LaTour line of $100+ wines consistently garner great reviews. In the pas. they’ve sold their entry level Rutherford cab wines at Costc. along with their mid-priced Tapestry wine. On occasio. you’ll see this Napa Cab for about $1. but recentl. this Napa cab went “on sale” for about $11 — $7 less than you’d pay for this wine at other retailers. This is an excellent value for folks who appreciate or want to learn about Napa cabernet and should be around at this discounted price for most of February. In our efforts to endeavors to discover (and support) boutique winerie. sometimes we forget that the large corporate wineries know what they are doing and can produce some kick-ass wine at very competitive prices. Beaulieu is bi. but you can taste why they’ve been successful. Right out of the bottl. this cab has lovely leg. red fruit. (primarily plum and cherry) with almost no tartness. Full bodied but not too tannic or swee. with a moderate length finish thanks to just the right amount of oak. This is a great socializin. dinner wine with light but flavorful taste with great dept. balance and complexity. When you sip thi. you experience what makes Napa cabs so unusual and special. At $1. you want to buy a case or two of this and enjoy it for the next few years. –Review by Michael .. Rating: 9. Price: $10.9. Costco Item #: 17192. Purchased at Costco in: San Dieg. CA

Review_name: 2010 Kirkland Signature Series Brunello di Montalcino
Review_content: This Kirkland Brunello has been one of the most talked about wines among our readers and now that I finally found it at my local Costc. I can jump into the conversation and state that I’m in complete agreemen. and this is clearly one of the best buys in Costco stores today. If you’re a fan of Italian red. you already know Brunellos rarely come in this price range ($24.99) so it’s even more impressive to find one at that price that is really good too. Brunello is made from the Sangiovese grape which is the powerhouse Italian red varietal that you findin manypopular wines from Italy including Chiant. and Super Tuscans where it is often times the primary blending ingredient. I’ve had my fair share of Brunello. having sampled quite a few when we were writing our book on Italian win. and had I tasted this blin. I most certainly would be pegged it for a Brunello costing much more. On the pour you can see slight signs of a little age settling in around the rim as this wine wasaged in oak for 36 months. Color is medium to dar. and the body in the mouth is on the medium to medium plus side. That’s part of what I love about Brunellos; they pack in a lot of flavor but the package is light and delicate. I just let the wine breathe for an hour in a few glasses and now I’m back. Aromatics have improved; earth. touch of perfume; red fruit flavor. rich and dee. sour cherr. cranberr. a little mint; tannins are still a bit tight and would age this wine nicely over time if you laid a few dow. which I might do for fun. Finish really stick. and is the highlight of the wine in my opinion. This one stays with you and is awesome with food. Weenjoyed it with homemade meatballsandspicy red sauceand it was perfect. I’d certainly recommend trying this win. and if you enjoyed it as much as I di. you might want to buy them up because I don’t think they’ll be around long with all the buzz surrounding it. CostcoWineBlog.com Rating: 92-93 point. Costco item number: 100115. Purchased at Costco in: Atlant. GA (Kennesaw)

I finally found it at my Costco – the Kirkland Rioja that so many readers have been raving about. I’m a little late to the ball game on this on. and several readers have posted tasting notes on this wine in the comments sections of our other reviews. And I’m thrilled to finally be able to chime in on the dialogue and we can use this post to discuss the wine further in the comments below. The beauty her. in my opinio.isreally that this wine cost only $6.99 at Costc. and at that price it’s an insanely good deal. This is a real Rioja (Rioja cork. and it’sbi. juic. loaded with flavo.even aged a bit so it’s soft and fluffy in the mouth – clearly a wine that you would pay at least double this price for. Earthy and oaky on the nose; red cherr. licorice andstrawberry flavor. followed by a touch of that signature Rioja vanilla and then finishing spicy and herbal with a lingering rosemary note. It’s hard to believe that this wine is only $6.99. No wonder everyone has been writing in about buying this by the case. This is a case buy wine that red wine fans will adore. I’ll be going back for mor. and am hoping it doesn’t disappear too fast. CostcoWineBlog.com Rating: 88 Point. Costco item number: 91705. Purchased at Costco in: Atlant. GA (Kennesaw)

We’ve come across a particularly nice Chardonnay value in the Costco aisle offered by the Washington wine powerhous. Chateau Ste. Michelle. This is not a boutique wine: CSM is the state’s oldest (and one of its largest) wineries. The winemakers at CSM know winemaking (especially riesling and chardonnay). This particular chardonnay wine is from their Indian Wells vineyard and is one of their “premium wines”. Currently on sale for $9.9. it is an excellent value proposition. (According to Cellartracker.co. the same wine goes for $13-17 per bottle). So the Costco buyers have secured a decent discount. There’s a lot to like here for $9.99. Light straw gold in colo. Butterscotch and pineapple on the nose; echoed on the rich palate. It is close t. but not quit. the California buttery style of Chardonnay. Its acidity is medium minu. but good for rich “white wine” foods. It has a pleasant warm oaky nos. buttery and tasty on the palat. some citrus notes. We call this a Goldilocks win. as it doesn’t have too much of anything – just a very balance. lighter style of chardonnay that’s very easy to drink and would be a safe recommendation to about any chardonnay fan. This is a very nice win. currently at an excellent price poin. that is produced by a winery that knows how to produce a reliable and tasty product. — Reviewed by Michael . Rating: 88
Price: $9.99
Costco Item #: 449644
San Dieg. California

I’m liking this WA State Cab for $14.99. Over the last hour it’s developed into an expressive and rather interesting wine in this price range. I typically do enjoy Northwest red. and went into this one with fair expectation. but have to say it certainly me. if not exceeded those. Costco’s price on this wine is very competitive too. I’ve seen this same bottle closer to $20 at my wine warehouse. The nose opens with flora. earth and violet aroma. then serves up flavors of cherr. red licorice (more Nibs than Twizzlers. transitioning to more dark fruit with a little cocoa and cigar box towards the finish. There are definitely a few other varietals in here so I had to track those down. The wine is comprised of 75% Cabernet Sauvigno. 16% Merlo. 5% Malbec and4% Cabernet Franc. This is a bi. full bodied Cab at a great price. I’m going to add to our Top Picks list. CostcoWineBlog.com Rating: 90 Point. Costco item number: 61977. Purchased at Costco in: Atlant. GA (Cumberland)

Charles & Charles is a collaboration between Charles Smith (of his namesake winery and K Vintners) and Charles Bieler. Smith is a former rock band manager and while on the road developed a particularly good sense for rockstar wines. A self-taught winemake. Smith’s wines have garnered a lot of media attention and furrowed brows by other wineries that can’t produce value wines as enticing as Smithicized wines. This 2013 Chardonnay was sourced from five vineyards across the Columbia Valley AVA including two in the Wahluke Slop. two in the Yakima Valle. and another in the Columbia Basin. The winemakers describe this wine as dominated by quinc. apples and caramel. Hmm. not sure that does it justice. At $8.7. you get a really good chardonnay; perhaps even absurdly good. Lifted by a hint of pineapple and coconut and rounded out with a solidly silky finish this is a heckuva good wine. It avoids the oak-overload that plagues some California chards with about 22% barrel fermentation and aging to help round out its bright and fresh acidity. It is a nicely balanced wine with just the right amount of fruit and acid graced by a lovely mouthfeel and long finish. I sampled it over two days with poultr. vegetables and guacamole. They all paired wonderfully. An added plus: it tastes great even without food. This wine generally sells for $10 dollars at other retailers and $14 directly from the winer. so Costco’s offering about 15-40% off retail. Not a mind-blowe. but for about $. you may get one of the nicer chardonnays on the market – one that earns the right to be favorably compared to Columbia Crest’s more expensive H3 chard. — Reviewed by Michael . Rating: 9. Price: $8.7. Costco Item #: 16723. Purchased at Costco in: San Dieg. California

Review_name: 2012 The Sum from The Seventy Five Wine Company
Review_content: I haven’t reviewed one of The Sum red blends in quite a while but I was looking forward to this 2012 vintag. which was a stellar season for California. Plu. thiswine is made by Tuck Beckstoffe. a legend of the are. and The Sum marks the lowest entry point I’ve seen into his wines. The last vintage of the Sum thatI tried was the 2010 which I thoroughly enjoyed and rated 89 Points. This 2012 though is a step up and was specially priced $3 off at my Costcobringing the already reasonable normal $18.99 price tag down to $15.9. making it one of the best bargains I’ve seen in the warehouse in a while. This wine is comprised of 75% Cabernet Sauvigno. 15% Petite Sirah and10% Syrah. The wine pours an inky purpl. dark but you are able to see through it slightlyin good light.Floral nose with some dried fruit and herbs. In the mouth the wine is full bodied andric. but balanced nicely between the varietals. Flavors of dark frui.noted blueberr. jamm. blackcherrywith some cigar box cedar and a dry fruity finish. For fans of big fruit packed California red. this will be right up your alley. Be sure to look for it soon and hopefully you can still find the special $3 off pricing at your Costco. CostcoWineBlog.com Rating: 90 Point. Costco item number: 50544. Purchased at Costco in: Atlant. GA (Cumberland)

This is an unbelievable buy at Costco if you can still find it. This wine was held back by the producer to age for 10 years and is making its way through stores now. But don’t expect it to last. Robert Parker rated the wine 96 points and it can be scored at Costco for $39.99. I’m going to suck it up and buy 3-4 on my next visit if they are still around. This wine starts with toasted oak aroma. very Tuscan; you could easily think you are getting into a Super Tuscan or Brunell. not a Spanish Rioja. Then the wine gets a little herbal as it begins to open up in the mout. leading to dark fruit flavo. heavy blackberry with smoky tobacco and campfire notes on the finish. It’s a super complex wine that develops across multiple layers. A real treat to enjoy over a few hours to taste the changes. Finish is super long and sticky. A real ge. and maybe one of the best values I’ve found at Costco this year. CostcoWineBlog.com Rating: 93 Point. Costco item number: 1132. Purchased at Costco in: Atlant. GA (Kennesaw)

Review_name: 2013 Dobbes Family Estate Grand Assemblage Pinot Noir
Review_content: This is a lovely Oregon Pinot at Costco for $19.99 and a perfect companion for almost any food. We enjoyed this on a crisp fall evening with butternut squash ravioli (also from Costc. if you haven’t tried it ye. you should) and it was a great accompaniment. Good pinots like this are so versatil. and fun to enjoy any time of the year. This is one of the better Pinots I’ve tried in recent memory that falls in this price range. The wine starts with dried fruit and floral aromas with a touch of spic. followedbydistinct red fruit flavo. strawberr. raspberry and cranberry. It’s juicy in the mout. soft into the finish that brings a touch of spice and rounds out with some lingeringred cherry flavor and sticky acidity. This wine is really enjoyable all the way through. Pinot lovers will definitely enjoy this on. and I think fans of other fruit driven red wines will also find something to like. I’m putting this one on the Top Picks list. CostcoWineBlog.com Rating: 91 Point. Costco item number: 665459

An absolute gem of a red wine drinking perfectly right now. This was a surprise find for $16 at my Costco. When I’m looking for a very nice wine at a good pric. I typically gravitate to Spain and Portugal. In this case I actually had a higher priced Rioja in my hand and made a last minute switch to this wine. I’ve had this varietal blend before (Ramos too I believe. and something just felt right. Overal. this is a very elegan. well balance. flavor packe. enjoyable wine. Aromas of ripe fruit and dried herbs. In the mout. this wine is medium to full in bod. tight tannin. plenty of red fruit with chocolate undertones. Towards the end the spice character picks up. The finish is long and sticky. I’m really enjoying this win. even more than I originally thought that I might. The blend is 40% Aragonez (which you may know as Tempranillo.30% Syrah and30% Touriga Nacional (Portugal’s premier grape and one that is gaining in popularity around the globe). If you see this wine at your Costc. think about being a little adventurous and dropping it in your cart. I have a feeling you might be surprised. CostcoWineBlog.com Rating: 91 Point. Costco item number: 86062. Purchased at Costco in: Atlant. GA (Kennesaw)

This McLaren Vale Shiraz from Two Hands hits big in every way. I have tried prior vintages of the higher priced Bella’s Garden Shiraz from Two Hands and thoroughly enjoyed them. This lower priced entry ($26 at my Costco) turned out to bea real find. I posted a photo to Twittershowing how the Costco bin had the choice between the 2012 and 2013 vintages. If you’re looking for a particular vintage of a win. I suggest you dig through the bins just to check if the one you want is there. I’m doing this now on the 2011 Napa Cab. digging through the bottles hoping to find the 2012s that are starting to arrive. (I summed up this and many other Costco wine buying tips in this story). O. back to the Angel’s Share. This wine is big and dens. loaded with flavor. Any red meat dish would be an ideal companion here. Pours blood red in the glass. Nose was peppery with herbal aromas. Flavors in the mouth are spicy cherr. jammy blackberry and blueberr. along with cola (a little Dr Pepper); the wine finishes dr. slightly smoky and spicy. This is a great buy on a stellar under $30 wine. I imagine this wine could hold up and perhaps improve over the next few years. So I may be heading back to cellar one or two for a bit to see how they develop. I’ll report back in 2017. CostcoWineBlog.com Rating: 90 Point. Costco item number:93094. Purchased at Costco in: Atlant. GA (Kennesaw)

Review_name: 2013 Kirkland Signature Stags Leap District Napa Cabernet Sauvignon
Review_content: , I didn’t hesitate for long dropping this one in my cart. I’m a big fan of Stags Leap wines and you rarely see a Stags Cabernet for the price I found this bottle at ($19.99). And the wine was exactly what I hoped it would be – a bi. ric. nicely structured red. It has thatsignature Stags Leap flavorthat only wines from this part of Nap. with its dense volcanic soi.seem to have. The nose on this wine is really vibran. hitting your nose two to three inches away on your approach to the glass; floral aromas with a hint of smoke. Flavors of dark fruit: blackberr. dark chocolate and a touch of black licorice/anise. Dusty and dry on the finis. just begging to have been preceeded by a little red meat. This is a solid buy in Napa Cabernet from a high demand district that is rarely priced this low. I’m going to put this bottle on the Top Picks list. If you know Stags wine. this is a no brainer. If no. here’s one to look for. And note: at my Costco in the Atlanta are. I almost walked by this bottle. There were a handful of thesebottlessharing a wooden box with another wine. So I almost overlooked it. It made me wonder how many of these bottles are floating around out there. Hopefully you can find i. but I would buy it if you see it. CostcoWineBlog.com Rating: 90 Point. Costco item number: 50508. Purchased at Costco in: Atlant. GA (Cumberland. Also note: As I mentioned I love Stag’s Leap wine. particularly the reds. Some of my favorite producers in the area are Cliff Lede (also one of the best to visi. a rock ‘n roll winery. Stags Leap Winery (especially their SLV Cabernet from a good year. Pine Ridg. Reynolds (also a great one to visit. and lastly Baldacc. which is a small winery you have to visit. Their high end Brenda’s Vineyard Caberne. again on a good yea. is among my current favorite Napa wines.

I thought this was an amazing buy for only $11 at Costco. I’m a fan of King Estate wine. so was anxious to dig into this bottle which is priced below their other wines that you can frequently find at Costco too. For an entry level whit. regardless of your favorite varieta. this is one you will definitely want to consider. Unusual depth and character for so such a low priced wine. This one kept my attention throughout an entire evening of grilling pineapple/bacon chicken sausage with vegetablesand relaxing on a beautiful evening post dinner. This wine offers excellent fruit flavor (mostly appl. pear andpeach)matched with a vanilla/cream character. That’s why it serves equally as a dinner complement and dessert. I’m going tokeep a few of these on hand to close out the summer months. At this pric.it’s hard to find such a versatil. crowd pleasing wine as I found this one to be. An addition to ourTop Picks list. CostcoWineBlog.com Rating: 88 Point. Costco item number: 52196. Purchased at Costco in: Atlant. GA (Cumberland)

Review_name: 2012 Shea Wine Cellars Estate Pinot Noir
Review_content: Unlike the less expensive wines available at Costco and reviewed here (like the well-regarded/excellent Schug. this is a complex and full-bodied Pinot Noir. While Shea’s vineyard and estate fruit hearkens from the same area in Oregon as Domaine Serene (the wineries are only about 5 miles as the crow flies) and Ken Wright (who uses Shea in their staple wine. there are some faint differences which rule in favor of Shea. Compared to those pricier and more well-known wine. Shea’s namesake production simply manages to be better. Upon opening the bottl. it begins as an incredibly smooth wine. There is little to no discernible oak and the Pinot fruit shines right through the nose. There is the traditional black cherr. eart. and some floral to mix it up – all which changes given the time in which you let the bottle open (Pinot Noirs don’t really need decantin. and with no sedimen. it would be wrong to use one). The taste is terrific with continued smoothness from the earlier experience coupled with a richness unlike anything similar in price or origin. As the wine opens u. it yields some light spice (depending on your palette. coco. and more berry. It lacks the significant acidity which its peer wines are often overburdened wit. but also is devoid of too much fruit which would disrupt pairing with food. Costco appears to be all about wines which are drinkable no. and this is no exception. Sur. this isn’t a single block wine nor the choicest fruit as in Shea’s $86 Homer versio. but it’s a definite winner. The only burning question is whether it’s worth the premium over the other excellent wines sitting next to it at Costco. But given unlimited fund. I’d buy a case of this tomorrow. — Reviewed by Josh . Price: $34.9. Rating: 9. (would be higher if not for the price premium)

, As we continue our summer Chardonnay scouting expeditio. we’ve come across a particularly nice Chardonnay value in the Costco aisles. This was a shy and skittish selection – the bottles were tucked away in the Chardonnay aisle with literally nothing drawing attention to it. Ye. it’s sort of a big deal: it is the first US brand developed by the Taub famil. owners of leading importer Palm Bay International. Grown in the Russian River are. and winemaker Tom Hinde has done an admirable job creating a Burgundy type wine (although without the minerality). The wine is divided between tank and barrel (French oa. 30% new) And the price is right at just under $13.  (it sells for between $14-17 in other wine stores. This is delightfully floral with notes of appl. pear and grapefruit; a very crisp win. with layers of citrus. Despite the rich accen. it’s light-bodied and easy to lik. offering subtle complexity and a very clean finish. Very fruit forwar. ripe apple/pear with citrus note. just a hint of oak with well-balanced acidit. nice complexity; full of varietal character and harmonious with food. Its acidity and minerality are balance. leaving a lingering fruit finish. Very nice wine at an excellent price point.  Don’t miss this one. Reviewed by Michael . Rating: 8. Price: $12.9. Costco Item #: 97604. Purchased at Costco in: San Dieg. California

Review_name: 2013 Kirkland Signature Cotes du Rhone Villages
Review_content: Kirkland Signature wines historically offer a nice bang for the buck (like most Kirkland items at Costco. andthe KS Cotes du Rhone Villages always seems to lead the way in terms of unbelievable value since it is priced at only $6.99. You just can’t find wines from this region priced that low so I highly recommend seeking this one out. And I’ve already heard from a few reader. and our contributor Jos. who have found and enjoyed this wine. Many of the same characteristics I noted in the 2011 vintage apply to the 201. and I’ll probably score it similarly in the 88-89 range. This is an impressive little packag. a lot of flavor packed into a wine with a lighter body than I was expecting. It’s a little unassuming at firs. but in a good way once you get in. Nose is pepper. earthy. The blend is standard Rhone:Grenach. Syrah and Mourvedre. Flavors of dark frui. blueberr.blackberr. jammy; a fair amount of depth for a $7 wine. Leather towards the en. into the finish that’s dust. dry and lasting. Overal. one of the best buys I’ve found at $7. I can’t think of any other wines priced this low that I felt had this much going on. Worth a try. CostcoWineBlog.com Rating: 88 Point. Costco item number:88777. Purchased at Costco in: Atlant. GA (Cumberland)

I’ve been slacking a bit on reviewing some Merlots and thought this bottle from Freemark Abbey would bea nice way to get going again. I love their Cabernet Sauvignon. and really want to try some of the straight Cab Francs they’re putting out. But I found the Merlot at Costco. Price was $28.99 which is pretty good since I’ve seen this one closer to $35 before ($35 is full retail. Wine.com has it for $27). It might seem like a lot to throw down for a Merlo. especially considering their Cabs are just a bit mor. but I really enjoyed this one. 2012 is obviously the year you want from Napa. This is a combination of mountain fruit and fruit from the Napa floor. It’s 86% Merlot along with some other Bordeaux varietals so that helps balance the wine. It’s a juicy on. fruit forward; definitely a crowd pleaser for red wine fan. who might not peg this for a Merlot; reminds me of a right bank Bordeaux to a degree. Oak element is mild so the fruit really comes through. Dark frui. blueberr. cherr. blackberry flavors. Finishes smooth and clea. a touch dry and sticky. Overal. an enjoyable wine. I wish we could get in at a slightly lower price poin. but that asid. I’d recommend for most red wine fan. even those non-Merlot drinkers. CostcoWineBlog.com Rating: 90 Point. Costco item number: 6282. Purchased at Costco in: Atlant. GA (Kennesaw)

Review_name: A To Z Oregon Pinot Noir (A Vertical Tasting, 2012 and 2013)
Review_content: Reviewed by Josh . Recently I had the rare – and accidental – opportunity to do a “vertical” tasting after buying two bottles of wine at Costco. In the stor. I wasn’t fully paying attentio. and after arriving hom. I learned that I had one each of the 2012 and 2013 vintages of the A to Z Pinot Noir. The two wine. while simila. had some clear differences. The 2012 was more traditional Oregon Pinot in quality. It had a pleasant cherry nos. followed by a lightly acidic (taste) – as expected – but softened over time. As I’ve purchased it about a dozen time. this wine has been extremely consistent – thanks in part to the screw top and Costco’s supply chain quality. 2012 is on the left; 2013 on the righ. On the other han. the 2013 surprised me in a positive wa. and behaved more like a California Pinot Noir in initial and overall taste profile. There was much more frui. which proved to be a far more pleasant wine to drink without food. All is relativ. though – this is not a “jammy” Syrah varieta. nor a more ric. woody and higher alcoholic content Zinfandel. As seen in the phot. the color is clearly lighter – more ruby red than darker purple. The only downside of the 2013 is that it began to break down sooner – the 2012 was a better (more composed) wine after being open for a few hours. So in summar. for $15.9. this wine is a great bargain. Both versions are equally good in their price range. But if given the optio. I would choose the 2013. Price: $15.9. Rating: 88

, I’m a big fan of this Chardonnay. It just hits me right on every accor. and I’ve heard from quite a few readers who have also enjoyed previous vintages. So to see the 2012 pop up was a real treat. It pours a medium yellow; aromas of citrus and a bit of oak. Mid-end palate is really where I think this wine shines. The citrus flavor turns to more of a butte. butterscotch toward the finis. surrounded by just enough oak to add another layer of complexity. Long finish. A bit of minerality towards the end. But butterscotch being the key elemen. and one that I don’t normally gravitate t. but somehow they pull it off. This is a great food wine too. We paired with some of the wild sockeye salmon that’s at Costco right now (Copper river made its run by the wild sockeye is really good too. And the prices are unbeatable). I gave the 2011 vintage of this wine a 91 and will keep my rating the same. I’ll also add to the Top Picks list. Chardonnays can be really different and appeal to people in different ways. For m. this one really works. (I didn’t get the price or item number. My son had a picture drawn on the back of the receipt and then we lost it. I believe it was around $20 which is less than prior years on a better vintage). CostcoWineBlog.com Rating: 91 Point. Purchased at Costco in: Atlant. GA (Cumberland)

Albarinos are perfect for breaking up the summertime routine of defaulting toyourstandardSauvignon Blancs and Chardonnays when seeking hot weather wine refreshment and summer fare accompaniment. We made a spinach and kale salad (most fresh from the garden. threw in some beet. goat chees. carrot. almonds and a homemade vinaigrett. and this bottl. and it was perfect on a 98 degree evening in Atlanta. The Burgans Albarino is a signature showcase of this varietal. I’ve been enjoying them for year. and haven’t noticed this at my Costco in at least a few years. It’s too bad because Costco’s $11.59 price tag is clearly the lowest I’ve ever seen. This wine is $17.99 at Total Wine right across the street from the Costco I shop at. So stock up if you enjoy Albarinos and see it. The wine is straw golden in color. Tropical fruit on the nos. and then flavors of pineappl. grapefrui. lots of apricot and pear in the mouth. Finishes with a little acidity and tart. This is all done very fruit forwar. no woo. very clean and crisp.My wife was looking for a beach wine and after one sip she knew this wasexactly what she wanted. Good price on an enjoyable summer favorite. I’m going to put on our warehouseTop Picks list due to Costco’s unbeatable price on this bottle. CostcoWineBlog.com Rating: 87 Point. Costco item number:27267. Purchased at Costco in: Atlant. GA (Kennesaw)

I’ve been meaning to get around to trying this Costco Rose. It’s been a reader favorit. a frequently mentioned wine across the social networksand was priced at $18.99 at my Costc. which I think is an ok price (I’ve seen it elsewhere closer to $15). We decided to pair this on a summer day with a fresh Greek salad consisting of cucumbe. tomat. avocado andfeta with ahomemade Greek Vinaigrette. It was anexcellent combo. The wine is made from a blend of Rhone varietals including Grenach. Syrah and Mourvedre. But this is a completely different interpretation that your standard Rhone red. and I found it to be really refreshing.The color is a silver pink. Flavors of red berr. strawberr. cherr. raspberr.with a mouthfeel that’s super dr. not sweet at all. Paired with the sala. this wine was superb. On its own it was equally nice to enjoy on a nice late summer night. This is a fun one. Bring it to a dinner part. or give this bottle as a gift. It will please a wide range of wine drinkers. I’m adding to our Top Picks selections too. CostcoWineBlog.com Rating: 90 Point. Costco item number: 373866
